Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = e^{i\omega t} \\) where \\( \omega \\) is a constant frequency. We analyze the impact of the linear operator \\( L \{z\} = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}z(t)dt \\), known as the Laplace transform, on this function over time.

Given the transformed function after intervention, \\( L\{e^{-at}z(t)\}(s) \\), can the presence of the damping factor \\( e^{-at} \\) and its parameter \\( a \\) be uniquely determined together with \\( \omega \\), only by knowing the transformed result?
Explanation: The Laplace transform post-intervention, \\( L\{e^{-at}z(t)\}(s) = \\frac{1}{s + a - i\omega} \\), exhibits a pole at \\( s = -(a - i\omega) \\). Both the damping factor parameter \\( a \\) and the frequency \\( \omega \\) can be uniquely extracted from the real and imaginary parts of this expression, respectively.
